document.docTitle: On the taxonomy of the Zodarion thoni species-group (Araneae, Zodariidae), with description of a new species with an unmodified embolus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the taxonomy of the Zodarion thoni species-group (Araneae, Zodariidae), with description of a new species with an unmodified embolus

emphasis.docTitle:
On the taxonomy of the
Zodarion thoni
species-group ( Araneae , Zodariidae ), with description of a new species with an unmodified embolus

paragraph.emphasis: National Museum of Natural History, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 1 Tsar Osvoboditel Blvd., 1000 Sofia , Bulgaria

subSection.paragraph:
A new species of
Zodarion
, belonging to
Z. thoni
-group, is described from the Taurus Mountains, Turkey . By now, it is the only known species with an unmodified embolic tip in this group. The syntypes of
Z. rhodiense Caporiacco, 1948
,
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
, and the holotype of
Z. granulatum KulczyÅski, 1908
are revised.
Zodarion rhodiense
sp. reval. is revalidated and
Z. nigrifemur
syn. n.
is assigned as its junior synonym.

Key words: Ant-eating spiders ,
Asia Minor
,
new synonymy
, revalidation , taxonomy

The genus
Zodarion Walckenaer, 1826
comprises 169 valid species, partially split into species groups. The focus of the present study is the
Z. thoni
group, which distribution is restricted to the Eastern Mediterranean, Caucasus and the Balkans. The group currently consists of six species:
Z. thoni Nosek, 1905
,
Z. granulatum
,
Z. reticulatum
,
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
,
Z. beroni Komnenov & Chatzaki, 2016
, and
Z. imroz Dimitrov, 2020
. Nosek (1905) described
Zodarionthoni
from Anatolia , Turkey . KulczyÅski (1908) described
Zodarion granulatum
,
Zodarion reticulatum
and
Zodarion thoni cypria
. The latter was elevated to a full species level by Wunderlich (1980) . Dunin & Nenilin (1987) questioned the identity of
Z. cyprium
and considered it to be conspecific with
Z. thoni
, without synonymizing them explicitly. This opinion was not followed by Levy (1992) and Kovblyuk (2003) , who considered
Z. cyprium
a separate species. Caporiacco (1948) described
Zodarion rhodiense
with two subspeciesâthe nominate
Z. rhodiense rhodiense
and
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
. Brignoli (1984) re-described the nominate subspecies and elevated it to full speciesâ
Z. rhodiense
. Bosmans (2009) synonymized
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum
and elevated
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
to full species. In the same paper, he diagnosed the
Z. thoni
-group and summarized its complex history. Wunderlich (2022) described
Zodarion parashi
, which was subsequently synonymized with
Z. granulatum
by Bosmans & Gavalas (2023) . All of the species in this group have modified tip of the embolus, which was used by Bosmans (2009) to diagnose the group.

While studying this group I recognized one undescribed species from Turkey with an unmodified tip of the embolus, kept in the collection of the Museum of Natural History Vienna. It is described in the present paper. Examining its closest relatives revealed another problem in the taxonomy of the group, concerning
Z. rhodiense
and
Z. nigrifemur
. After studying the syntypes of the two species, as well as the holotype of
Z. granulatum
Idiscovered that
Z. rhodiense
and
Z. nigrifemur
were conspecific, but different from
Z. granulatum
. Hence, the synonymy of
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum
proposed by Bosmans (2009) was not correct. Therefore, Itake the occasion to remove its synonymy, to revalidate the species
Z. rhodiense Caporiacco, 1948
, and consider
Z. nigrifemur Caporiacco, 1948
as its junior synonym.

The material is preserved in 75% ethanol. The specimens were examined using a Zeiss Stemi 508 stereomicroscope. The palps were dissected to be studied, photographed, and illustrated. The photographs of the palp were taken with Canon EOS 1100D, attached to a Carl Zeiss Amplival compound microscope. The body was photographed with the same camera, attached to a Zeiss compound microscope. The images were stacked using Helicon Focus stacking software and then processed in Photoshop. The drawings were made with Wacom tablet and Adobe Illustrator software. The color is described from a specimen, kept for a long time in ethanol. All measurements are in mm. The leg measurements formula: total length (coxa + trochanter, femur, patella, tibia, metatarsus, tarsus).

Abbreviations: Morphology. ALEâanterior lateral eyes; AME âanterior median eyes; Câconductor; Eâ embolus; PLEâposterior lateral eyes; MAâmedian apophysis; PMEâposterior median eyes; RTAâretrolateral tibial apophysis. Institutions. MZUF âMuseum of Natural History, La Specola, Florence, Italy ; MZVâMuseum and Institute of Zoology, Warsaw, Poland ; NMW âMuseum of Natural History, Vienna , Austria .

sp. reval. , male, habitus. 1

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. The type series is sufficiently small, and the diagnostic characters remain stable (see Figs 1â9 ). Consequently, the designation of a Lectotype (and Paralectotypes ) seems unnecessary, as it does not confer any discernible nomenclatural advantages (See Article 74.7.3 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature (1999)) .

Diagnosis (partial, male).
Zodarion rhodiense
sp. reval. belongs to
Z. thoni
species-group, judging from its large rectangular median apophysis and long, arch-shaped embolus ( Figs 4â6 ). It is morphologically most close to
Z. thoni
because of its very similar lanceolate tip of the embolus, with a specific knob on the prolateral side. The only difference between the two is that in
Z. rhodiense
sp. reval. the embolic tip is thinner, longer, and twisted backward ( Figs 4â6 ), while in
Z. thoni
it is wider and shorter ( Bosmans 2009 : figs 168â169; Lecigne & Henrard 2022 : fig. 5BâC).

Description. Male ( Figs 1â9 ). Measurements. Total length 4.25; carapace length 2.05, width 1.50; sternum length 1.20, width 1.01; chelicerae length 0.66, width 0.39; clypeus height (measured under the AME) 0.39; cymbium length 0.94; eye diameters: AME 0.13, ALE 0.09, PME 0.8, PLE 0.09; abdomen length 2.02, width 1.67; spinnerets length 0.3; leg Iâ7.88 (0.88, 1.97, 0.72, 1.54, 1.72, 1.05), leg IIâ7.18 (0.81, 1.72, 0.66, 1.25, 1.84, 0.90), leg IIIâ7.48 (0.76, 1.82, 0.63, 1.42, 1.87, 0.98), leg IVâ8.45 (1.13, 2.43, 0.75, 1.30, 1.92, 0.92).

Colouration ( Figs 1â3 ). Carapace brown with dark brown pattern. The fovea is well-visible, dark brown. Legs with dark brown femora, as dark as the carapace pattern. The other leg segments yellowish. Sternum yellowish with light brown pattern. Chelicerae the same color as the carapace. The palpal femora brown, the other segments yellowish to light brown. Dorsal abdominal scutum black, with a metallic glint, without a pattern. Abdomen almost black, but lighter than the scutum. There is a small white spot above the spinnerets, another (bigger) one ventrally, and a broad diagonal white stripe on each side. The lateral and abdominal white areas connected. Colulus well visible, yellowish, with brown rim. Spinnerets yellowish with light-brown pattern in the base. AME significantly larger than the other eyes. Chelicerae with opistognathic position. Femoral organ with 3 setae on femur I [Since the material is in very bad condition, it was not possible to examined them on the other legs, but see Lecigne & Henrard, 2022: 36 , fig. 3AâD]. Abdomen with 2 spinnerets and narrow dorsal scutum, not covering its whole length. Colulus shaped as a broad, hairy plate.
Variations of the body size (based on the adult syntypes only). Carapace 1.80â2.08; abdomen 1.80â2.02.

Remarks. When synonymizing
Z. rhodiense
with
Z. granulatum , Bosmans (2009)
referred to the description and drawings of
Z. rhodiense
providedby Brignoli (1984: figs 50â53). They indeed correspond to
Z. granulatum
, but this is due to misidentification. Brignoli (1984) has described and depicted
Z. granulatum
instead of
Z. rhodiense
. I was able to find and examine the syntypes of the two subspecies
Z. rhodiense rhodiense
and
Z. rhodiense nigrifemur
. Males have fully identical tips of the embolus ( Figs 4â6 ) and no other somatic or genital differences. Even the main diagnostic feature (the color of the femur) is identical between the two ( Figs 1â3 ). However, the tip of the embolus clearly differs from those of
Z. granulatum
( Fig. 18 ). The females collected with both
Z. r. rhodiense
and
Z. r. nigrifemur
were not conspecific with the males and belong to
Zodarion frenatum
( Figs 10â12 ). I include also photographs of
Z. frenatum
from Bulgaria for comparison ( Figs 13â14 ). Ido not update the female diagnosis because there were no females belonging to
Z. rhodiense
sp. reval. among the syntypes . Since Caporiacco (1948) named the species
Z. rhodiense
in the original description, this name has priority and is revalidated, whereas its subspecies
Z. r. nigrifemur
n. syn.
is assigned as a junior synonym to the nominate one.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
â holotype , Turkey , Taurus Mountains , Mersin province , ÃamlÄ±yayla , Namrun Castle , pine forest,
05.06.1964
( NMW )
.

Etymology .
Named after the Namrun castle, the type locality of the species; noun in apposition.

Diagnosis. The species belongs to
Z. thoni
group (sensu Bosmans 2009 ), judging from the large, rectangular median apophysis of the male palp with the typically twisted distal processus ( Figs 16 , 19 ). The male differs clearly from all the other species in the group by the shape of the embolusâlong and thin, ending with needlelike unmodified tip ( Figs 16, 17 , 19, 20 ) vs. ending with different modifications in
Z. thoni
( Fig 5 ),
Z. reticulatum
,
Z. rhodiense
,
Z. beroni
and
Z. imroz
or truncated in
Z. granulatum
( Fig 18 ). Also, the new species differs by the broad and rectangular distal extension of the median apophysis ( Figs 16 , 19 ) vs. with narrower tip in all the other species.

Description. Male ( Figs 15â17 , 19â20 ). Measurements. Total length 4.04; carapace length 2.04, width 1.44; sternum length 1.04, width 0.80; chelicerae length 0.69, width 0.36; clypeus height (measured under the AME) 0.24; cymbium length 1.04; eye diameters: AME 0.11, ALE 0.06, PME 0.5, PLE 0.06; abdomen length 2.00, width 1.33; leg Iâ7.17 (0.78, 1.74, 0.58, 1.43, 1.64, 1.00), leg IIâ6.48 (0.67, 1.59, 0.55, 1.17, 1.53, 0.97), leg IIIâ6.45 (0.73, 1.56, 0.55, 1.05, 1.73, 0.83), leg IVâ9.00 (1.03, 2.13, 0.61, 1.80, 2.39, 1.04).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 15â18. 15â17
Z. namrun
sp. n.
, male holotype. 18
Z. granulatum
, male holotype (ARA025383); 15 habitus dorsal; 16, 18 left palp, ventral; 17 left palp, retrolateral. Scale bar = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Palp ( Figs 16â17 , 19â20 ). RTA elongated, curved distally, with pointed tip. Bulbus oval, elongated. Embolus long and thin, starting approximately at 8 oâclock position and ending at 4 oâclock. The tip of the embolus thin, unmodified. MA large, shaped as an irregular rectangle, with characteristically twisted distal extension ( Figs 16 , 19 ).
Distribution. Known only from the type locality in the Taurus Mountains (Namrun), Turkey .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 19â20.
Z. namrun
sp. n.
, male holotype, left palp. 19 ventral, 20 retrolateral. Câconductor, Eâembolus, MAâ median apophysis, RTAâretrolateral tibial apophysis, Tâtegulum. Scale bar = 0.5 mm.

subSection.paragraph:
In the diagnose of the
thoni
- group, Bosmans (2009: 220) describes the embolus as being âsemi-circular, linear, describing nearly half a circle, terminally widened into a small, specific knobâ.
Zodarion granulatum
does not fully fit this diagnose. Although its embolus tip is also modified being truncated, it does not end in a knob. With the new species described here, it is clear that the
Z. thoni
- group contains also species with unmodified tip of the embolus and this should no longer be a diagnostic character for it. Despite that, the group remains consistent and is well characterized by the large, rectangular median apophysis with specifically twisted distal (prolateral) part as well as by the long, arch-shaped embolus. The females have narrow, coiled ducts of the vulva.

The present study does not resolve all the uncertainty in the taxonomy of the
Z. thoni
species-group. With the holotype of the
Z. thoni
lost, its identity remains unclear. Here Ifollow Bosmans (2009) and Lecigne & Henrard (2022) who separate
Z. thoni
and â
Z. nigrifemur
â (= Z. rhodiense sp. reval.), but in my opinion the difference between the two species is too small, and could be just variation. Such minor differences could depend even on the slight variations of the angle when taking photographs/drawings. The different descriptions of the males ( Nosek 1905 , Bosmans 2009 , Lecigne & Henrard 2022 , and the one in the present paper) overlap significantly and it is difficult to extract reliable diagnostic features out of them. Moreover, no significant difference could be observed between the females.

Unfortunately, all the available material for this study was too old and not suitable for sequencing. Amolecular phylogeny of the group is urgently needed to properly delimit the species boundaries and distribution ranges.

Ithank Christoph HÃ¶rweg ( NMW ) for giving me the opportunity to study the material in the collection of the Vienna Museum, and Wioletta Wawer (MZV) for sending me photographs of the holotype of
Z. granulatum
. Ialso thank Christo Deltshev and three anonymous reviewers for the constructive critical comments. This study was supported by a Marie SkÅodowska-Curie Individual Fellowship H2020-MSCA-IF-2019 (895672) funded by the European Commission and by the projects âCybertaxonomic approach to phylogenetic studies of model invertebrate genera (Invertebrata, Arachnida, Insecta ), clarifying the problems of origin, formation and conservation of the invertebrate fauna of the Balkan Peninsulaâ, National Science Fund, Ministry of Education, Youth and Science of the Republic of Bulgaria , Grant KP-06-Ð21/1- 17.12.2018 .
